p: More than two-thirds of human virus species are zoonotic, that is, they are capable of infecting vertebrate hosts other than Homo sapiens. By far the most important nonhuman host taxa are other mammals, with rodents and ungulates most commonly identified as alternative hosts, followed by primates, carnivores, and bats. A minority of the zoonotic viruses (less than 20%) is also known to infect birds; very few have been reported from vertebrates other than mammals or birds ( Antia et al., 2003).
